Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Aerosol Formation from Agricultural Volatile Organic Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is investigating the potential for agricultural emissions of nitrogen and sulfur gases from sources such as dairy farms, piggeries, and other animal production sources to lead to the formation of very small particles in the atmosphere. Previous studies have shown that gas phase compounds related to waste management practices from animal agriculture could influence the formation of atmospheric particles. This project includes laboratory, field and modeling studies to investigate the environmental fate of nitrogen and sulfur compounds from these sources.

An environmental chamber will be used to quantify secondary aerosol formation potentials at different relative humidities and temperatures for select amines (diethylamine (DEA), trimethylamine (TMA), butylamine (BA), a diamine, or NH3) oxidized in the presence of an organosulfur compound (methanethiol, dimethylsulfide (DMS), or dimethyldisulfide (DMDS)) or hydrogen sulfide. The investigators will perform field sampling of particulate matter and precursors at agricultural operations in Kentucky at the USDA-Agricultural Research Station (ARS) laboratory to determine the impact of elevated amine and sulfur concentrations on atmospheric chemistry.

Kinetic modeling calculations will help clarify the sequence of chemical reactions responsible for the data seen in laboratory experiments. This will, in turn, help explain emission rates observed in field observations. The investigators expect to elucidate the atmospheric oxidation routes for reduced sulfur compounds and amines. Empirical estimates of the aerosol formation potential of key agricultural emissions will be developed for use in predicting local and regional air quality impacts and emissions inventories of the reduced nitrogen and sulfur species will be developed as an additional input to air quality models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemical formation of particulate matter air pollution (also known as aerosols) is important to study for health and environmental reasons.  Breathing in aerosols can cause an increase in respiratory illnesses, depending on the size, chemical composition, and concentration of the particles in the air.  Aerosols of different chemical species can either absorb or reflect radiation as well, which has a direct impact on Earth?s energy balance and climate.  Particles in the atmosphere can lead to reduced visibility in the atmosphere and often act as nuclei for water condensation to form clouds. 

Our research focused on how two types of gases?compounds containing nitrogen (alkylamines) and compounds containing sulfur (sulfides) can react to form particulate matter.  Amines are similar to ammonia but with organic groups attached to it in place of hydrogen atoms while sulfides are similar to hydrogen sulfide but with organic groups attached.  Both these classes of compounds can be emitted from animal feeding operations, but not much is known about how these gas phase emissions react near the source to produce particulate matter.  We do know from previous work that amine gases can be either oxidized to form less volatile amines that can deposit on particles or they can react with an acid to form a salt. Sulfide compounds perform easy chemistry in the atmosphere to produce acidic compounds We want to understand chemically how the proximity of amines and sulfides to each other do this. 

Our research had a two pronged approach incorporating field measurements in locations with agriculture and controlled laboratory experiments at an environmental chamber to understand reaction chemistry. We measured these compounds at a source (a poultry house in Southern Kentucky) and at an ambient monitoring site in Cache Valley, Utah. We measured minor concentrations of amine and sulfide concentrations from the poultry house in Kentucky.  Significant amounts of sulfides were measured in Utah. 

The second part of our study was to understand reaction mechanisms of amines and in a controlled environment.  It is impossible to control the weather in field measurements. Humidity, light, and temperature all have impacts on particle formation. In the environmental chamber, we can hold the humidity, light, and temperature constant, and we know what chemical species we are adding to the chamber as well.  We performed a variety of experiments with several different nitrogen compounds (ammonia, butylamine, diethylamine, and trimethylamine) and several different sulfur compounds (hydrogen sulfide, methanethiol, dimethylsulfide, and dimethyldisulfide).  We used a variety of analytical tools to understand what chemical species were forming in the chamber, such as mass spectrometry, ion chromatography, particle sizing and density measurements.

We found that the inorganic compounds (ammonia and hydrogen sulfide) did not react in any combination to form particles to an appreciable amount. Experiments with dimethylsulfide produced sulfate aerosol via sulfuric acid. Dimethyldisulfide had a tendency to form methanesulfonic acid particles. Both sulfuric acid and methanesulfonic acid can produce particles in the presence of amines. When comparing how much aerosol derived from the amines, trimethylamine formed the most particles and butylamine the least.  Overall, we found that having nitrogen and sulfur compounds mixed together in the environmental chamber does lead to significant particle formation. Concentrations of compounds measured in the field are comparable to those used in the environmental chamber, indicating that these reactions are likely important in the atmosphere.
